text.author: Rose Spielman, Kathryn Dumpner, William Jenkins, Arlene Lacombe, Marilyn Lovett, Marion Perlmutter
text.title: Psychology
text.summary: This excerpt from a psychology textbook explains how the brain uses abstract concepts, such as 'democracy', and prototypes like Rosa Parks or Mahatma Gandhi for categories such as 'civil disobedience', in order to organize the large amounts of information in sensory experience.

figure.rend: The outline of a human head is shown. There is a box containing “Information, sensations” in front of the head. An arrow from this box points to another box containing “Emotions, memories” located where the person’s brain would be. An arrow from this second box points to a third box containing “Thoughts” behind the head.
